aThis is the last note on preliminary linear algebra. For people who have been following along they might notice that much of the "nomal" stuff about matrices are not stressed or even mentioned so far in this series. To finish strong, we will focus on determinant and trace of matrices in our last note. This first-operator-then-matrix approach is what Axler's book is best known for. To the author, such a method helps to cultivate your intuition about linear maps and operators. If you can prove things without referring to matrices, you are doing the "hard part" of the work to understand linear algebra. Once you survive the "hard" work, manipulation of matrices might be more transparent. Like previous notes, here we still assume vector spaces VV is nonzero and finite-dimensional over the field F=CF=C.1. Trace 1.1. Change of Basis 1.2. Trace: A connection between matrices and operators 2. Determinant 2.1. Determinant of an operator 2.2. Determinant of a matrix 2.3. Volume 2.3.1. Polar coordinates 2.3.2. Spherical coordinates 3. Where to go from here? 1. TraceAs a starter, we need to revisit the way matrix is define. For any operator T∈L(V,W)T∈L(V,W), we need to one basis of VV and another basis of WW to define the matrix that represents TT. Let v1,...,vnv1,...,vn and w1,...,wmw1,...,wm be the two bases of VV and WW, respectively. Then the matrix of TT with respect to the two bases is M(T,(v1,...,vn),(w1,..,wm))M(T,(v1,...,vn),(w1,..,wm)), which has a shape of m-by-n. We will make it explicit the information of bases in the definition of matrices as it helps us to prove some results in the subsection below. 1.1. Change of BasisSuppose v1,...,vnv1,...,vn is a basis of VV, and the identity operator I∈L(V)I∈L(V) satisfies Ivi=viIvi=vi. So M(I,(v1,...,vn),(v1,..,vn))M(I,(v1,...,vn),(v1,..,vn)) is a n-by-n matrix with its diagonal entries all being unity. Now, let u1,...,unu1,...,un be another basis of VV, M(I,(v1,...,vn),(u1,...,un))M(I,(v1,...,vn),(u1,...,un)) is a matrix that changes basis of every vector v∈Vv∈V from v1,...,vnv1,...,vn to u1,...,unu1,...,un. Change of basis has extensive use in physics as it usually is a way to simplify the problem. Here we are interested in using M(I,(v1,...,vn),(u1,...,un))M(I,(v1,...,vn),(u1,...,un)) to relate trace of operators to trace of corresponding matrices. For an operator T∈L(V)T∈L(V), we have discussed its matrix M(T,(v1,...,vn))M(T,(v1,...,vn)), i.e., we use only one basis to represent the matrix. If we use two different bases to represent matrices of operators, we can then rewrite the rule of matrix multiplication as the following

Trace: A connection between matrices and operatorsWe will first give the definitions of traces of operators and matrices, separately. While their definitions look different, we will prove that they are essentially the same thing. Also, the trace of a matrix is invariant under the change of basis.
Definition1Suppose T∈L(V)T∈L(V)- If F=CF=C, then the trace of TT is the sum of the eigenvalues of TT, with each eigenvalue repeated according to its multiplicity.- If F=RF=R, then the trace of TT is the sum of the eigenvalues of TCTC, with each eigenvalue repeated according to its multiplicity.The trace of TT is denoted by trace TT.
The TCTC above is the complexification of operator TT acting on a real vector space. For the sake of completeness, we define TCTC and complexification of real vector space as the following:
Definition2Suppose VV is a real vector space.- The complexification of VV, denoted VCVC, equals V×VV×V. An element of VCVC is an ordered pair (u,v)(u,v), where u,v∈Vu,v∈V, but we will write this as u+ivu+iv.- Addition on VCVC is defined by(u1+iv1)+(u2+iv2)=(u1+u2)+i(v1+v2)(u1+iv1)+(u2+iv2)=(u1+u2)+i(v1+v2)for u1,v1,u2,v2∈Vu1,v1,u2,v2∈V.- Complex scalar multiplication on VCVC is defined by(a+bi)(u+iv)=(au-bv)+i(av+bu)(a+bi)(u+iv)=(au-bv)+i(av+bu)for a,b∈Ra,b∈R and u,v∈Vu,v∈V.
Definition3Suppose VV is a real vector space and T∈L(V)T∈L(V). The complexification of TT, denoted TCTC, is the operator TC∈L(VC)TC∈L(VC) defined byTC(u+iv)=Tu+iTvTC(u+iv)=Tu+iTvfor u,v∈Vu,v∈V.
The matrix of TCTC equals the matrix of TT. When 𝜆𝜆 is a real eigenvalue of TT, then it is also an eigenvalue of TCTC. Suppose VV is a real vector space, T∈L(V)T∈L(V), and 𝜆∈C𝜆∈C. Then 𝜆𝜆 is an eigenvalue of TCTC if and only if ⏨𝜆𝜆¯ is an eigenvalue of TCTC.Recall that characteristic polynomial of an operator is (z-𝜆1)d1(z-𝜆2)d2⋯(z-𝜆m)dm(z-𝜆1)d1(z-𝜆2)d2⋯(z-𝜆m)dm where 𝜆i𝜆i and didi are eigenvalues and their corresponding multiplicities (dimensions of generalized eigenspaces). We expand such a polynomial to get ,zn-(𝜆1+⋯+𝜆1⏠⏣⏣⏣⏡⏣⏣⏣⏢d1+⋯+𝜆m+⋯+𝜆m⏠⏣⏣⏣⏡⏣⏣⏣⏢dm)zn-1+⋯+(-1)n(𝜆d11⋯𝜆dmm)zn-(𝜆1+⋯+𝜆1⏟d1+⋯+𝜆m+⋯+𝜆m⏟dm)zn-1+⋯+(-1)n(𝜆1d1⋯𝜆mdm) which results in the following lemma:
Lemma4Suppose T∈L(V)T∈L(V). Let n=dimVn=dimV. Then trace TT equals the negative of the coefficient of zn-1zn-1 in the characteristic polynomial of TT.
For the trace of a matrix, we define it as the following
Definition4The trace of a square matrix AA, denoted trace AA, is defined to be the sum of the diagonal entries of AA.
With Definition 4, we can easily show that
Lemma5If AA and BB are square matrices of the same size, thentrace(AB)=trace(BA).trace(AB)=trace(BA).
Proof: Let AA and BB be two n-by-n matrices, then the jjth diagonal element of ABAB is n∑k=1Aj,kBk,j∑k=1nAj,kBk,j. Proof: From Lemma 3, M(T,(u1,…,un))=A-1M(T,(v1,…,vn))AM(T,(u1,…,un))=A-1M(T,(v1,…,vn))A with A=M(I,(u1,…,un),(v1,…,vn))A=M(I,(u1,…,un),(v1,…,vn)), sotraceA-1M(T,(v1,…,vn))A=⏠⏣⏣⏡⏣⏣⏢trace(AB)=trace(BA)traceM(T,(v1,…,vn))AA-1=traceM(T,(v1,…,vn))traceA-1M(T,(v1,…,vn))A=⏟trace(AB)=trace(BA)traceM(T,(v1,…,vn))AA-1=traceM(T,(v1,…,vn))which gives traceM(T,(u1,…,un))=traceM(T,(v1,…,vn))traceM(T,(u1,…,un))=traceM(T,(v1,…,vn)) as desired.□We are now ready to prove
Theorem1Suppose T∈L(V)T∈L(V). Then traceT=traceM(T)traceT=traceM(T).
Proof: Because trace of matrix is invariant under the choice of basis (Lemma 6), we only need to show traceTtraceT equals to traceM(T)traceM(T) for some bases. Definition5Suppose T∈L(V)T∈L(V).- If F=CF=C, then the determinant of TT is the product of the eigenvalues of TT, with each eigenvalue repeated according to its multiplicity.- If F=RF=R, then the determinant of TT is the product of the eigenvalues of TCTC, with each eigenvalue repeated according to its multiplicity.The determinant of TT is denoted by detTdetT.
If 𝜆1,…,𝜆m𝜆1,…,𝜆m are the distinct eigenvalues of TT (or of TCTC if VV is a real vector space) with multiplicities d1,…,dmd1,…,dm, then the definition above impliesdetT=𝜆d11⋯𝜆dmm.detT=𝜆1d1⋯𝜆mdm.From the expansion of characteristic polynomial at (7), we have
Lemma9Suppose T∈L(V)T∈L(V). Then the characteristic polynomial of TT can be written aszn-(traceT)zn-1+⋯+(-1)n(detT)zn-(traceT)zn-1+⋯+(-1)n(detT)
We now show the following lemma can be proved easily using Definition 5.
Lemma10An operator on VV is invertible if and only if its determinant is nonzero.
Proof: Suppose VV is a complex vector space. An operator T∈L(V)T∈L(V) is invertible if and only if 0 is not its eigenvalue, resulting in nonzero determinant. If VV is a real vector space, we have again TT is invertible if and only if 0 is not an eigenvalue of TT, which happens if and only if 0 is not an eigenvalue of TCTC. Thus, we have detT≠0detT≠0□ Definition of determinant also gives a new way to define the characteristic polynomial of operators as shown below.
Lemma11Suppose T∈L(V)T∈L(V). Then the characteristic polynomial of TT equals det(zI-T)det(zI-T).
Proof: First we notice that -(T-𝜆I)=zI-T-(z-𝜆)I-(T-𝜆I)=zI-T-(z-𝜆)ISo 𝜆𝜆 is an eigenvalue of TT indicates that (z-𝜆)(z-𝜆) is an eigenvalue of zI-TzI-T. The equality also implies that dim null(T-𝜆I)dimV=dimnull (zI-T-(z-𝜆)I)dimVdimnull(T-𝜆I)dimV=dimnull(zI-T-(z-𝜆)I)dimVi.e., the multiplicity of 𝜆𝜆 equals the multiplicity of z-𝜆z-𝜆. Let 𝜆1,...,𝜆m𝜆1,...,𝜆m be the eigenvalues of TT, and d1,...,dmd1,...,dm corresponding multiplicities. det(zI-T)=(z-𝜆1)d1⋯(z-𝜆m)dmdet(zI-T)=(z-𝜆1)d1⋯(z-𝜆m)dm, where the right hand side is exactly the characteristic polynomial of TT. If VV is real vector space, we apply the complex case to TCTC to give the same result.□Finally, as a special kind of operator, we have the following result regarding the determinant of isometries.
Lemma12Suppose VV is an inner product space and S∈L(V)S∈L(V) is an isometry. Then |detS|=1|detS|=1
This result should be obvious on complex vector spaces as isometries have absolute values of their eigenvalues being unity. By definition of the determinant on real vector spaces, we have detS=detSCdetS=detSC and thus |detS|=1|detS|=1, completing the proof.2.2. Determinant of a matrix To define determinant of an arbitrary matrix, we first introduce the concept of permutation and its sign.
Definition6- A permutation of (1,…,n)(1,…,n) is a list (m1,…,mn)(m1,…,mn) that contains each of the numbers 1,…,n1,…,n exactly once.- The set of all permutations of (1,…,n)(1,…,n) is denoted perm nn.
Definition7- The sign of a permutation (m1,…,mn)(m1,…,mn) is defined to be 1 if the number of pairs of integers (j,k)(j,k) with 1≤j<k≤n1≤j<k≤n such that jj appears after kk in the list (m1,…,mn)(m1,…,mn) is even and -1-1 if the number of such pairs is odd.- In other words, the sign of a permutation equals 1 if the natural order has been changed an even number of times and equals -1-1 if the natural order has been changed an odd number of times.
With Definition 6 and Definition 7, it's possible to prove that
Lemma13Interchanging two entries in a permutation multiplies the sign of the permutation by -1.

2.3. VolumeDeterminant has one important application in undergrad-level mathematics, i.e., in computing volumes and integrals. In this section we first lay out critical tools and then investigate volumes and and integration through linear algebra. Recall that if VV is an inner product space and T∈L(V)T∈L(V), then T†TT†T is a positive operator and hence has a unique positive square root,T†TT†T. By the polar decomposition, there is an isometry S∈L(V)S∈L(V) such that T=ST†TT=ST†T thus|detT|=|detS|detT†T|detT|=|detS|detT†T because eigenvalues of the square root are nonnegative. Eqn.(10) and Lemma 12 lead to the following
Lemma19Suppose VV is an inner product space and T∈L(V)T∈L(V). Then|detT|=detT*T.|detT|=detT*T.
We now study the relation between determinant and volume by calculating volumes of arbitrary subsets of real vector spaces. The volume of arbitrary subset could take any shape geometrically, which make the calculation hard. We will relieve this issue by dissecting the volume into smaller "boxes" whose volume is well defined and easy to calculate. A box is defined as the following
Definition9A boxbox in RnRn is a set of the form{(y1,…,yn)∈Rn:xj<yj<xj+rj for j=1,…,n},{(y1,…,yn)∈Rn:xj<yj<xj+rj for j=1,…,n},where r1,…,rnr1,…,rn are positive numbers and (x1,…,xn)∈Rn(x1,…,xn)∈Rn. The numbers r1,…,rnr1,…,rn are called the side lengths of the box.
and its volume is defined as
Definition10The volume of a box BB in RnRn with side lengths r1,…,rnr1,…,rn is defined to be r1⋯rnr1⋯rn and is denoted by volume BB.
For an arbitray volume 𝛺𝛺, we can write it as a subset of a union of many small boxes, as inidicated in the definition below:
Definition11Suppose Ω⊂RnΩ⊂Rn. Then the volume of ΩΩ, denoted volume ΩΩ, is defined to be the infimum of volume B1+ volume B2+⋯,  volume B1+ volume B2+⋯, where the infimum is taken over all sequences B1,B2,…B1,B2,… of boxes in RnRn whose union contains ΩΩ.
Since we seek a relation between volume 𝛺volume 𝛺 and an acting operator TT, we use the notation of T(𝛺)T(𝛺) to represent the set of {Tx: x∈𝛺}{Tx:x∈𝛺}. Let TT first be an positive operator, then volume 𝛺volume 𝛺 and volume T(𝛺)volume T(𝛺) are related through the lemma below:
Theorem3Suppose T∈L(Rn)T∈L(Rn) is a positive operator and Ω⊂RnΩ⊂Rn. Then volume T(Ω)=(detT)( volume Ω).  volume T(Ω)=(detT)( volume Ω). 
Proof: Consider an arbitrary positive operator T∈L(Rn)T∈L(Rn). By the Real Spectral Theorem, there exist an orthonormal basis e1,…,ene1,…,en of RnRn and nonnegative numbers 𝜆1,…,𝜆n𝜆1,…,𝜆n such that Tej=𝜆jejTej=𝜆jej for j=1,…,nj=1,…,n. That is, TT stretches the jth jth  basis vector in an orthonormal basis by a factor of 𝜆j𝜆j. Because volume behaves the same with respect to each orthonormal basis, we should have volumeT(Ω)T(Ω) equal to volume ΩΩ multiplied by a factor of 𝜆1⋯𝜆n=detT𝜆1⋯𝜆n=detT. □For TT being isometry, we have instead
Lemma20Suppose T∈L(Rn)T∈L(Rn) is an isometry and Ω⊂RnΩ⊂Rn. Thenvolume T(Ω)=T(Ω)= volume ΩΩ.
Now we can prove that for arbitrary operator T∈(Rn)T∈(Rn) changes volume by a factor of |detT||detT|:
Theorem4Suppose T∈L(Rn)T∈L(Rn) and Ω⊂RnΩ⊂Rn. Thenvolume T(Ω)=|detT|(T(Ω)=|detT|( volume Ω)Ω).
Proof: By the Polar Decomposition, there is an isometry S∈L(V)S∈L(V) such thatT=ST†T.T=ST†T.If Ω⊂RnΩ⊂Rn, then T(Ω)=S(T†T(Ω))T(Ω)=S(T†T(Ω)). Thusa

=|detT|( volume Ω)□

Now we can state the change of variables integration formula. Some additional mild hypotheses are needed for ff and 𝜎′𝜎′ (such as continuity or measurability), so we will not worry about the rigorous proof of the following theorem.
Theorem5Suppose ΩΩ is an open subset of RnRn and 𝜎:Ω→Rn𝜎:Ω→Rn is differentiable at every point of ΩΩ. If ff is a real-valued function defined on 𝜎(Ω)𝜎(Ω), then∫𝜎(Ω)f(y)dy=∫Ωf(𝜎(x))|det𝜎′(x)|dx∫𝜎(Ω)f(y)dy=∫Ωf(𝜎(x))|det𝜎′(x)|dx
Theorem 5 is called a change of variables formula because you can think of y=𝜎(x)y=𝜎(x) as a change of variables. Where to go from here?This ends my notes on preliminary linear algebra. Anything beyond what's been showing in this series of notes can be termed as "advanced" aspects of linear algebra. For people who are more interested in applied mathematics, Hubbard's "Vector Calculus, Linear Algebra, and Differential Forms: A Unified Approach" could be your next step. People love the book because it discusses interesting physics problem (e.g., Maxwell's equations) by setting up tools from linear algebra. For self-learners, the book is also a good choice as it is self-contained and is accompanied with a solution manual. If one demans broad scope of applications of linear algebra, then Brunton's "Data-Driven Science and Engineering: Machine Learning, Dynamical Systems, and Control" will likely satisfy one's curiosity. The author is not a pure-math person, so any recommendation from me is not justified for the book of grad-level linear algebra. But the Springer graduate textbook seems to be a decent one for smart minds seeking to understand elements introduced here in greater detail.Like what is preluded in my first note on linear algebra, this series serves as a solid prequel to my journey into quantum computing and quantum information theory. My current life has nothing to do with these two subjects but the impetus of nudging myself to the frontier of humanity sustains over the years. Needless to say, I believe(maybe religeously) that many problems, whether they are scientifically challenging or socially controversial, can be solved by running qunatum algorithm on quantum computers. When such achievements happen, I want to be there among people who dream big and move quick. Sooner or later, I will write new notes again with interesting stories to tell about quantum algorithm and quantum information theory. So please be patient my dear readers and thank you for following along with me so far.
